text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonyous questions. 

Career stage: senior (8+ years)

"My company is growing rapidly and so is our marketing team. There are so many inputs for content strategy to support business direction. 

It feels like we're growing in every area at once, all in ways I haven't done or led before. I don't think I have impostor syndrome, rather, I feel like I just dove in headfirst and have no idea which way to swim. 

Any advice on how you've worked through similar high-growth and high-learning periods?"

the title is a bit misleading but you may find this article useful - it talks about taking on unfamiliar marketing channels: <https://www.reforge.com/blog/crossing-the-canyon-leading-your-first-marketing-team>

if you can get your company to get you Reforge course access i highly recommend their marketing strategy course - it's for people in exactly your situation

attachments.title: Crossing the Canyon: Leading Your First Marketing Team — Reforge
attachments.text: Brittany&nbsp;Bingham &nbsp;is the VP of Marketing at Guru , a collaborative knowledge management solution where answers find you--everywhere, every time. Previously, Brittany worked as VP of Marketing & Growth at RaiseMe and as Sr. Director of Growth Marketing at SurveyMonkey w
attachments.fallback: Reforge: Crossing the Canyon: Leading Your First Marketing Team — Reforge

if you can get your company to get you Reforge course access i highly recommend their marketing strategy course - it's for people in exactly your situation

text:
Hello, Anonymous! I can relate to parts of your story. I have a degree in English & Writing, but I honestly don’t talk about it that much (and no one ever asks about it) because it’s from a small, regional college no one really knows about. And my career has been a winding one where my longest tenure is 3 years, and the rest of my stints have been about a year due to a lot of things – at first it was because I was just taking jobs to gain experience & exposure, then it was a little bit out of boredom, and recently, it’s been because I’ve been recruited away to other jobs, or I’ve had big lifestyle changes (I had a baby!), and I need a schedule that works.

All of this to say, here’s what I’ve done when I have felt similarly:

• Start volunteering to do content/marketing work for a nonprofit. This looks great on a portfolio, and it can truly give you invaluable experiences and new skills. 
• Continue your education loudly and proudly. This could mean joining a local marketers group or taking courses (I hear Superpath has some great ones :slightly_smiling_face: Not only you can you put these on a portfolio, but talk about them in interviews and coffee meetings. Talk about why you joined and what you’ve learned. People LOVE working with people who care about what they’re doing. And you seeking out learning opportunities for more than just a line item on a resume is a great way to show that. 
• I created a virtual “praise jar” for myself. Sounds super cheesy, but I have a folder I keep in my inbox where I keep words of encouragement or compliments on my work. Sometimes, they’re just a couple of sentences saying, “This looks great!” Other times, their follow-ups to projects or meetings where someone I’ve worked with had some kinds things to share. This has really helped with my imposter syndrome, and there have been times where I’ve asked these colleagues to be used as references or use their words as part of a testimonial. 
• Finally, if you’re having a day where you’re feeling down about your experience, ask for a chance to show your stuff! Most jobs have a type of writing sample or assessment as part of the interview process. Embrace that, ask for it, and let there be where you shine. 
Rooting for you from afar!! You got this. :blush:

text: Love the praise folder. I need to do that so I can remind myself why I should be confident. :heart:

text: Yes! No one’s good at everything, but we all have things we love and excel in!!

elements.text: Yes! No one’s good at everything, but we all have things we love and excel in!!

text:
Our SEO agency has hired folks without college degrees from “traditional” backgrounds. They’re just as competent, hardworking, and intelligent as those with graduate degrees, if not more so. They present audit decks before clients at Fortune 100 companies and knock their socks off.

Part of the reason I love SEO. If you know your stuff and give a sh*t about the work, no one cares about degrees.

text: i agree. any company that hasn't trained its hiring team on implicit bias is not a place you wanna work anyways. many companies now do blind hiring. i don't mean to downplay this challenge, but keep looking. there are a lot of great businesses out there that need content help.

elements.text: i agree. any company that hasn't trained its hiring team on implicit bias is not a place you wanna work anyways. many companies now do blind hiring. i don't mean to downplay this challenge, but keep looking. there are a lot of great businesses out there that need content help.

text: this may be unpopular among your coworkers, but i'd go directly to your CMO and ask "what is the most important thing i can be working on?" they should be able to answer this very clearly. ideally, they've already laid out a vision but it sounds like that hasn't really happened. focus on the business goals: getting trials, MQLs, etc ... whatever is the goal for your company. it's very easy to start focusing on big editorial projects or traffic generating tactics when there's a lot of growth happening at once. find the most important thing you can help with and focus on that.

text: Own what you did and use it to your advantage. It must have brought you great experiences, learnings, etc. Which will all be beneficial. And honestly, if that's a red flag for them, you probably don't want to work at such a company anyway.

elements.text: Own what you did and use it to your advantage. It must have brought you great experiences, learnings, etc. Which will all be beneficial. And honestly, if that's a red flag for them, you probably don't want to work at such a company anyway.

text:
I'm gonna echo Jimmy and say that you really, really, really need to get a content strategy in place. One that determines where to play (channels, target personas, markets, etc) and how to win choices that will be the focus for your next 12 months. You can't do everything for everyone, that'll just lead to mediocrity. Ideally your company should have a clear strategy, on which the marketing strategy is based, on which you can set your content strategy. Good strategy is about choice, focus and winning. And from the sounds of it, that's what you would benefit from.

P.S. read Playing to Win, it's the best strategy framework out there and I wish I knew of it 10 years ago.
